segments.text: I go right back, and it starts in where I taped ...
I'll roll this back now and see what's happening.
Yes, it was erasing and taping over, so I'll just keep on talking now
and go back and start relating the story from where I was born at Remsen, Iowa, October the 7th, 1902.
My folks were living on the farm, as far as I know.
They were farming at that time.
My dad had been a drayman and a policeman in a town of 1,200 with 11 barrooms in it.
Those were the hectic days,
the pioneer days for western Iowa.
However, he farmed for some years.
He had three or four teenage boys at that time, so he thought it best to get out on the farm.
And for some reason or other, some land agent got a hold of him
and suggested that with a gang of boys like he had, he should be up in Canada
where land was cheap and a lot of room for expansion.
At that particular time, land in Iowa was selling,
well, roughly $80 an acre, where you could buy it up in Canada from $20 to $25 an acre.
But it was still the raw prairie.
It had to be broke up and put into cultivation before you could get anything off it.
And I guess they did a good job selling because dad had a lot of courage to move up in that godforsaken country
when he was in a good corn growing,
well-established community down there.
Well, we went up to Canada and they had about three boxcars of, I guess, mostly animals and some machinery.
They didn't have much machinery that you could use up in Canada.
But along with what they took along, they had a boxcar load of it.
And the rest was packed up in the passenger train and headed out.
I don't know the history of whether we—I'm sure we didn't have sleepers.
And we would have had to stop possibly overnight in Minneapolis when we got there.
I don't remember any of that.
I do faintly remember some of the train ride.
And there were—the two boys went with the boxcars of animals.
And they tell of all the fun they had riding in those side door pullmans,
if they call them, along with the animals,
all the way up from Remsen, Iowa, up to Sioux Falls, Sioux City,
and then up what they call the Sioux Line, up to Halbright.
And landed there on the 17th of March,
after a winter of the greatest snowfall the prairie had ever seen.
There was an estimated 36 inches of snow in Malapa that winter.
However, we landed at Halbright.
And now this is where my memory starts to get in gear.
We stayed in the hotel.
And I have a faint recollection of us being in this hotel.
This is Mother and all the children.
And then the boys and Dad arrived up there.
Well, I guess Dad was on the train with us.
And the boys came up with the livestock, and they had to unload.
And take it out to the farm.
Now, when they got out there, everything was under snow.
They tell that they had to dig into a snowbank to find the barn, a stable.
And I'd like to see, you know they - just what went on.
These guys coming from Iowa were, if they had six inches of snow there,
it was a big snowfall.
And here they come out with three foot of snow on the level.
We landed in a farm.
Six miles north of Halbright.
As I remember it, the house stood there for years and years after.
It was a two-bedroom house with a dining room, kitchen combined.
Or a dining room, living room combined, and quite a large kitchen.
And that house stood there for 20, 30 years after we lived in it for the first summer.
And I don't have any recollection of the sleeping arrangements,
where we all slept or anything.
But there were 12 of us.
But the youngest one wasn't born yet.
But there were 12 of us and mother and dad lived in that house.
And I can't figure out, we must have had solid mattresses on the floors
in order to find a place to sleep.
But first I remember the snow was all gone when I remembered that.
I can remember the ride out there with all the deep snow.
All you could see was snow.
As far as the eye could see, everything was white.
And then everything blanks out to me.
The next thing I can remember is that I would have been four and a half years old at that time.
And Liana was just past three, about 14 months younger than I was.
And the two of us walked across the mile where they were building the house on our regular farm
where we were going to live.
And I can remember just a faint recollection.
I guess we sneaked away without authority or anything.
We followed the trail, just a trail over there.
We followed the trail over there.
And the people in the house, they gave us cookies.
And I remember at Prune's, and Liana ate so many prunes that she had that nickname for years after Prune's Ache.
And then I have no recollection of us moving into that new house.
And that's funny.
And I don't remember, we moved over there that fall before winter set in.
That house was finished.
They put on, the original house was 14 feet by 20 feet with just a bedroom.
The whole upstairs was a bedroom and had a sort of a ladder to get upstairs.
Well, then they put on an extension with three bedrooms on it and a big dining room and a big living room
and a new stairway going up.
So we are well off because we had one of the bigger houses in the community.
And now we're talking into 1905.
I don't think I started school.
I must have been eight or nine years old when I started school.
We used to, we had two schools.
We started at Crow Lake School and that was two miles across the field.
But we had to go around the road.
And it was three miles to Crow Lake.
I can remember starting school there with the Orsted boys in person.
And Joe Barlow, Manning Body.
We were all in grade one.
And we were learning to the ABCs.
And I think we went there maybe two years.
And for some reason that school was closed down.
And then we went to DeVille School.
That was in the other direction.
Two miles again across.
Country, no roads.
We went there for, as I remember it, only one year.
And then Crow Lake School opened up again.
And we used to go around the road.
We drove horses the three miles.
And in the summer when they needed the horses in the field,
we walked the three miles.
And then at certain times of the year when it was dry enough,
we'd cut straight across the fields.
And that was just two miles going across.
And we used to go a walk, you know.
Mosquitoes would be so bad that we'd run to get away from them.
You'd run for a wave and then you'd slow down.
And then when they'd congregate again around you,
you'd run for another stretch ahead.
And that's the way you got your education.
Going foot to school and back.
Went there.
And when I was about ten years or twelve years old.
No, I wasn't twelve.
I was about six or seven.
And I went there.
No, I wasn't twelve.
I was maybe eleven.
And we were driving.
A single horse on a buggy.
And four or five of us would pile in that one-seated buggy.
Some would stand in the back, stand on the axle.
And an old great big horse would go back and forth.
And then, as I said, in the summertime when they needed them in the fields,
well, we would walk.
Well, I kept up.
That was my education, going to school.
But I will say this much,
when you're in grade, by the time you're in grade four,
you knew the times table.
Not just the four times.
You knew them right up to twelve times.
You knew spelling.
You knew geography.
You've got a good grounding in education.
There's no...
And writing.
They're very particular about your writing.
How you learn to write.
Make the letters, letter perfect, so to speak.
And then I...
Remember when I was about ten years old,
mother and dad took a trip back to Iowa via train.
For some reason, I was picked to go back with them.
I don't know if I was cute or so mean
they couldn't leave me at home or what it was,
but I went to Iowa with them.
I remember quite a bit about that trip,
about being at the various uncles' places.
And there were cousins there my age,
and we used to have a lot of fun playing.
It was in the fall of the year.
And then dad and I came back.
And mother stayed.
For some reason, she stayed.
And dad and I came back,
and I still remember us being in Minneapolis.
And he went down to a bar room
and took me down with him.
And there were all kinds of food.
You could have all the food you wanted for free.
A glass of whiskey at that time,
I guess, was about 25 cents.
And then as we went home that night,
I remember we went...
down the street,
and he said,
take a look down this window.
We looked down a basement window,
and here there were newspaper machines down there,
running all automated newspaper machines.
And the papers were coming out of there
just like nobody's business.
Then I remember going home from Minneapolis,
and dad had me singing.
I could sing pretty good.
Some of the old songs of the day.
And of course I'd sing,
and then everybody would hand me a dime.
I had dimes,
and I had porters on the train
that were selling candies, oranges, and apples,
and all sorts of good things.
No soft drinks in those days.
But I ate so much of this stuff I got sick,
and I started puking.
And that was the end of the singing.
This train ride to Minneapolis home was about,
oh, I would imagine,
about a 24-hour train ride
to Minneapolis, yes.
It would be, oh, 24 hours
to get from our place up to Minneapolis.
I don't remember anything else then until 19...
Oh, no, not any detail,
except milking cows and doing chores,
and you start doing that
when you're eight years old on the farm.
And at 11 years old,
I rigged up a team of horses on a hay rack,
and I was a straw monkey in the thrashing house.
At 12 years old,
I was out disking the land
with horses while the boys,
all the older ones,
were busy with the thrashing.
I couldn't remember that very well.
And you really had to work
when you were on the farm.
As soon as you were old enough
to pull weeds,
at five and six years old,
you're out pulling weeds in the garden.
And when I was 11,
that would have been 1913,
that's right,
then Sister Elijah was already
a novice in the convent,
I told you.
And Sister Hilary and I
both went to the convent that winter.
Mary got an education, too.
I was 11 years old.
Well, I...
Yeah, 11 years old,
and I had to do my own laundry.
You were on Saturdays,
you did your own laundry,
you washed your clothes,
got a change of clothes,
took a bath once a week,
I don't remember what bathtubs are.
I think we just took a bath.
The boys had their own room
down in the washroom,
in the laundry room.
We'd take a bath
out of an ordinary wash tub.
The food was plain and simple
and you had to eat
what was put on your plate.
There was a darn good reason
why you didn't eat it.
The problem was just that
because you didn't like it,
that you were sick or something
was the only reason
you got away from eating
the food that was put before you.
I remember I was in grade five,
and at Easter time,
we went home,
and I didn't go back.
I don't know why I didn't go back.
I don't remember if Sister Hilary
went back then or not.
But I started school at home,
and I wrote my grade five exam
at home.
Then I must have missed a year,
or I must have failed a grade,
because I went...
I passed my grade six,
I would have been about...
I must have been fourteen
or at least fourteen
or into my fifteenth year.
And then I started school
in grade seven.
Now, I would have been
about fifteen years old
that fall, I guess.
And the teacher and I
couldn't see eye to eye at all.
I guess I was as stubborn
as a fourteen or fifteen-year-old
can be.
And she and I were jangling
all the time as to saying,
go.
I was lipping her back
and whatnot.
And I was dissatisfied then,
and I said to Mother one day,
I want to quit school.
What are you going to do?
I said, I'll go trapping.
You could trap coyotes
and weasels
and what have you.
So she said,
well, if you don't like school,
well, you might as well quit.
And I quit school.
That was my education.
And many, many times
after I was grown up,
I thought,
and away from home,
I wish I'd have had more education.
However, I got by.
But I went on the trap line then.
Well, the trap line,
I was doing chores at home.
And I think Joe was in the Army
and Zip,
I don't remember if he went.
Maybe he was going to school
in Weyburn.
He went back to school
after he had quit for a while.
He went to Weyburn
and got his high school
up,
he got,
I would think he got his grade
nine and ten.
During that time,
well, I was at home
and we had a lot of livestock.
There's always so much work
to do around there.
It would take you
all forenoon
to get the chores done.
You had to clean the barns
every day at our place.
There was no other way around it.
Every animal had nice bedding,
nice straw place to lay down.
And then in the afternoon,
I'd go out and I'd set trap
and I'd try to catch the odd weasel,
a weasel skin is worth
maybe a dollar,
a dollar and a quarter.
And there were skunks around
and that skunk was worth
two and a half or three dollars.
And I caught the odd coyote
and they were worth
up to fifteen,
twenty dollars.
And so,
I was doing this trapping
on horseback.
I'd get on the old black mare,
old lady,
and I'd ride,
you know,
two or three miles away
from fifteen,
twenty blows zero.
You didn't stop for that.
Go and check your traps
if you caught something
and you brought them home
and you skinned them.
That was,
you kept busy all the time.
There was never a dull moment.
If you had any reading to do,
you did it at night
by coal or a lamp.
And reading wasn't as common
as it is today.
We had no radio at that time.
So you didn't get any news.
You were sort of blanked out,
you see.
The news you got was
when Dad'd come home from town,
he'd go to town
two or three times a week
and he'd always bring home
all the gossip
from the neighborhood,
you know,
what he had heard.
But we had telephone installed
when I was about twelve,
eleven or twelve years old
when we had the telephone installed.
So you had some communication
with the neighbors,
which was good for the women
in particular.
The boys,
we never talked back and forth.
We had neighbor boys,
but we wanted to talk to them.
We got on a horse
and rode over there,
basically in that way.
And life was simple,
very simple.
You worked hard
and you ate well
and you slept well.
And the next day
you got up
and it was the same thing
over and over.
And to get back to trapping,
after I was trapping
for a while,
I found out
there was a place
in St. Louis, Missouri
where you tip your highs.
There was no one duty
or anything
to get them across the line.
And I found out
that you got
about half again
as much for a coyote
to come down there.
So I started tipping them
down there
and then I got
a little bit more
money
and then I got
a little bit more
money
and skunks the same.
And then I found out
that I'd go out
and I'd buy them
from the neighbors
with the,
they would price them
at what they could get
in the Canadian market
and then I'd ship
to the States
and make myself
a nice profit
maybe a lot of times
50% profit.
I know in one case
I went to a fellow's place,
he had wolfhounds
and he went over there
and he had
10 or 12 coyote skins.
They were in bad shape
and they'd been
tore up
and they were bloody
and everything.
And he wanted
$10 a piece for them
and I had another
neighbor boy with me
and we went out of there
and we had,
I think we had
six or seven hides.
Some of them
were so bad
I wouldn't buy them
and they had averaged
me $3 a piece.
When I showed them
a few greenbacks
well,
he started
coming around.
I took them
down in the dark basin
with the coal lantern
and then I redressed
those hides
and I put on
a proper stretcher
and got them
the lead washed off
and cleaned up.
The first one
I sent away
I got
more for it
than I'd paid
for the whole lot.
And,
well,
that only lasted
so long
and then
this all
happened in about
one winter
that I was dealing
in furs
besides doing
the chores at home.
And that was
over with.
Well,
now I'm into
16 and 17 years old.
The war was on
and
it was
work,
work,
work.
Joe and Zip,
Joe went in the Army
and Zip was away
and I was
the main one.
Mac was,
what,
two and a half years
younger than me.
And we always had
to do all the chores.
So you worked,
worked,
and worked.
You would work
eight,
ten hours a day
every day
in the wintertime
as well as
in the summer.
Summertime
you worked from
five in the morning
till eight at night
every day,
six days a week
and then
do the chores
on Sunday.
We always milked
a half dozen cows
every day.
Besides,
it was all horse
farming in those days.
We had fifty,
sixty horses
around the farm
to see how to
look after.
In the summer
when I was,
what,
I was 13 years old
that fall.
Yeah,
this is hard to believe.
And Joe and Zip
were home
that summer.
And the three of us
hauled
rock
and gravel
all summer.
Had three,
three wagons
and horses.
And we'd go
up the hills
down to the river
and get
three loads of sand,
load them up
and take them home.
By the time
we got home
we'd leave at,
say,
seven or eight
in the morning.
By the time
we got home
it was four
in the afternoon.
And you had
to unload
your load
and then
do the chores
and then
be ready
to make
the trip
the next day.
And this,
this went on
I guess
a huge barn.
It was,
the foundation
was fifty-six
feet one way
and sixty feet
the other way.
And then
the contractor
come in
and he built
the barn.
He put down
the foundation
and everything.
Then we had
to haul
all those rock
in to fill
that foundation
in.
And then
filled it up
with sand
so they could
put a four inch
coat of cement
all over the barn.
It was an
almost thirteen
years old
that fall,
fall of
You want to
know about
work?
Well that was
work.
And that same
year before
that,
yeah,
we didn't
have a decent
well on the farm.
My brother
Max and I,
he would have
been about
ten I guess.
We were hauling
water with a
team of horses
and a big wooden
tank.
We used to
have to go
out and get
this water
and then haul
it down
and dump
it in the
big tank
in the pasture
where there
were about,
oh there
would have
been three,
four hundred
head of cattle
in that fifteen
hundred acre
pasture.
And that went
on until
we finally
got a well
at home
that wouldn't
go dry
and then we
didn't have
to haul
water anymore.
We probably
had to go
to school
when the
school term
started.
I don't
remember the
detail.
But that
gives you
an idea
of how
hard we
worked
when we
were young.
I often
said I
don't know
all the
help.
I was the
seventh son
and Max
was the
eighth one.
And as
soon as
it was
that they
used to haul
us a mile
and a half
away and
we would
dig post holes
all day
with a
post hole
order and
they would
come pick
us up
at night.
We would
have
our lunch
with us
out there.
But the
ball
prairie,
no trees
or no shade
or anything.
You stop
there working
That's through the 1914, 15, 16. It was the same thing. It was a repetitious thing.
Start on health. I wasn't going to school then. Work. 1917, bad, kind of a bad year.
1916, yeah. Then 17 is a short crop. 18 was a short crop. Now by this time, I'm 15 years old, I'm taking a man's place hauling bundles.
And I've been out hauling bundles that I'd be so tired when night came that I couldn't throw on the load anymore.
I'd just throw on a rack full and come in and my brother would unload them at the machine.
That went on.
1918, short crop. 1919, less crop again, but we always fared somehow.
We had a lot of, always raised 50, 60 hogs for sale and we always had hens, 125 hens around.
So we had our own eggs, our own pork, had our own beef.
We always had 50, 60 head of cattle and about that many horses.
So we were never short on work.
That was 1919.
We dried out.
1920, the hoppers came in and just about cleaned us out.
1921, then we got a crop.
And Dad bought a...
Well, in the meantime, 1918, he had bought a little Titan tractor.
It was about equivalent to four horses.
Or maybe, no, do more than that.
Do the work of about six horses.
But it was slow.
It would only travel about less than three miles an hour.
And in 1921, we had a crop.
Not a good crop.
It went about 20 bushels per acre, but a low grade of wheat.
Dad bought a small separator for that thrashing outfit.
And for some reason or other, while we were getting it rigged up, he and Jones, Jones
up were home that fall.
They got in a jangle of some kind and I was 19 years old that fall.
And so he got mad at them.
He said,
I was going to run this outfit and you guys can haul bundles.
So I was the chief cook and bundle washer around the thrashing machine.
I was running the thrashing outfit.
And I run that same outfit then in 1921.
22, we had a bumper crop.
23, we had a bumper crop.
24, the spring of 24, my dad died.
And that was a short crop that year.
It was only maybe 18, 15 or 18 bushels to the acre.
It was a short crop.
We were through harvesting real early.
In 24, in 24, yeah, we had finished.
And then I went up to Griffin.
I got a job running a thrashing outfit up there.
I just, what was I, 24?
I was 22 years old.
After that, I went thrashing for another fellow.
Oh, I could tell you
the incidental experiences that I had on those thrashing outfits.
When I got around and saw how those guys run a thrasher
after I had run one or not,
I was always so sure when I started that machine in the morning
that it wouldn't stop until night.
Nothing would happen.
It had eight or ten belts on it.
You had to have those all laced up properly and everything.
And you had to have everything set just right
that they couldn't plug the machine by throwing in too much at one time.
And all that.
Unless you thrashed,
it would be very difficult for you to understand what I'm talking about.
That was in 1924.
Then I was managing the farm when Dad died.
Bud was old enough then.
Bud was, what, 13 years old at that time.
And so between, he was going to school,
but when he wasn't to school, he was helping,
you know, taking a man's place.
He went to school and got his grade eight education.
Mac dropped out of school about grade seven, I'd say.
Not so far as he went to school.
And there wasn't much emphasis put on education in those days.
You know, it wasn't important that you had an education.
I don't know how Zip started back to school.
He became a teacher.
And Leona got her
grade nine, I think,
grade eight in the convent.
And then she went to high school in Halbright
and got her grade nine.
I think that's as far as she went.
And then she went to California.
And Sister Hilary, of course, went through
high school and became a teacher.
And Sister Eloy, she's the same.
Charles and all those guys.
I don't think any of them had a grade eight education.
They all
You could read and write and
know your arithmetic.
And that's as far as it went.
I've been talking silly for a half hour.
I'll take a rest now.
This is the morning of July the 23rd.
I have a few minutes to go before I go for coffee.
So I'll just continue about
the years before 1924.
You may think from what I said that we never had any fun.
It was allwork all the time.
But life is simple.
We made our own fun.
When I was growing up, you got to be a teenager.
You'd go to a schoolhouse dance two or three times a year.
There'd be dances in town that you'd attend.
No drinking or anything and dancing in those days
was all very primitive.
You never saw your neighbors during the week.
Only once a week that people would gather together.
The rest of the time, you just did your routine daily work.
On the weekend, in the summertime,
you'd get together and work up a ball team
between a bunch of the neighbors and play,
work up baseball.
And that's where you wired away the day.
Every other Sunday, we went to Mass in Halbright.
That took two or three hours out of the center of the day.
And...
Life was very, very ordinary.
In the summer, there'd be picnics here and there
that you'd attend.
You just went along.
And...
I don't know whether you enjoyed life or not,
but everybody did the same thing, and that's the way it was.
This is now on July the 20...
or August the 22nd.
So I'll try to continue.
I'm getting the story a bit mixed up,
but I'll go back to 1924,
where I mentioned that our crop was fair,
and that Dad had died that year.
And I'll go back and tell the story of when Dad died.
The fall of 23, Mother had gone to California.
She and...
Yeah, she went by herself.
And Leona stayed home to keep house.
It was Mac and Leona and I.
Bud was away to the convent.
Dad was there with us.
And Dad and I were hauling grain.
We had a big crop that year, and we were hauling grain.
There was no snow.
We were hauling with wagons all winter.
And he always complained that he wasn't feeling well, you know.
I would go and load the grain after the chores was done in the morning.
I would load the grain, and...
And then he and I would...
I'd haul it to town, and...
Slow process.
A team of horses moving at about three miles an hour.
So it took you about three hours to make the trip,
or more than that, four hours to make the trip to town and back.
And then it was chores time again.
We kept that up and kept up.
Finally, he said one day,
I'm going up to Griffin to see the doctor.
When he came home, and I said,
What did the doctor say?
Oh, the doctor said,
You're just a broken down old piece of machinery.
So he accepted that and kept on going.
And a couple of weeks later, he still wasn't feeling well,
so he went to Kenmore, North Dakota,
where there were some renowned doctors.
And he was gone a week,
and we hadn't heard anything from him,
or of him, I should say.
And finally, we got a card that he had been admitted to the hospital as a patient.
And following that, the next day,
we got a phone call that somebody had better come down.
He's a pretty sick man.
So I caught the train that night,
and I didn't have any money or anything.
I went to the banker,
and the banker was a good friend of Dad's,
and so he gave me money to make the trip.
When I got to Kenmore about 2 o'clock in the morning,
well, I phoned the hospital,
and they said he was resting fine.
And the next morning,
when I got up and I went to the hospital,
when I got there,
they said,
your dad just passed away.
So there I was,
with a dead father,
and didn't know which way to turn.
So I phoned back up to Harvard
and talked to my Aunt Mary.
She sort of directed me to
let the relatives in Iowa know about him,
to phone Mother in California.
And by that time,
she had worked her way up to Oregon,
was staying with my sister Emma.
So we got a hold of her there,
and I went back home.
We had the body shipped back to Halbright for burial,
and Mother got there by train.
It's funny how you could move around in those days.
She'd come all the way from Portland,
and we only held the funeral two days, I think.
She was there for the funeral.
And then I was in charge of the farm,
starting right then and there.
So that was in 1924.
And Mac and I run the farm.
Bud was there.
Leona was there,
but she went to California that winter again,
so we were alone with Mother.
And 25, good crap.
26, good crap.
26, some of the boys came up from California,
and they thought Mother was paying me too much money.
I had got $1,000 for the year,
and the next year I was to get $1,200.
And I got on my high horse,
and I said if they thought that was too much,
well, let somebody else run the farm,
and I'd go my own way.
And I headed for Iowa with my cousin Norbert Hemmer,
who was up for the harvest.
And...
Brother Mac took over the farm.
That was the fall of 26.
We'd really had a bumper crop that year.
But I went back down to Iowa,
and then from there on,
I started doing anything.
I didn't know where I was going or what I was going to do.
I had a few hundred dollars in my pocket.
I got down to Iowa to where I had a lot of relatives.
I'd been visiting down there two years before that,
so I knew all my relatives.
And I visited around for a while,
and finally one day they had the rain,
and it got all icy.
And I knew the blacksmith in town.
He needed some help.
He said, anybody know how to nail a shoe on a horse?
I said, no, I don't know how to nail a shoe on a horse,
but I know how to trim their feet.
So he started me trilling up their feet,
and he would put on the shoe.
And we got along.
He was paying me four dollars a day.
I don't know, I worked there about a week, I guess.
That was the end of that.
The ice melted,
and everything went back to normal again.
And then I hung around until right after the first of the year,
and a line gang came in town.
They were revamping or rebuilding power lines,
re-stubbing is what it was, a re-stubbing job,
putting a new stub in beside the old pole
to keep it from breaking off.
And through a tip, one of the girls in the café said,
if you're looking for a job,
I heard the boss say he's going to fire a guy.
So I went and asked the boss for a job,
and I, yeah, he says come to work tomorrow morning.
So away I went.
I knew nothing about what I was doing,
and I would have liked to about wore my hands out
for the first couple of days digging holes through frost.
And the fourth day, all of a sudden I got the knack of it,
and I got a hold of a set of better tools,
and I dug as many holes as anybody.
The fourth day and the fifth day,
I dug more holes than anybody,
and I never looked back from there on.
I was getting 35 cents an hour,
working nine hours a day,
paying my own room and board,
which you could get any place for a dollar a day.
So I was making about, what, three times twenty,
making a little over three dollars a day
and paying one dollar a day for room and board.
In the meantime, I had bought a car,
a Model T Ford for about $350.
Good, reliable car.
And then away I go,
and I follow the outfit.
They moved away from Worthington,
where we had started,
and one day the boss come along and said,
we're moving across the state,
down near Sioux City, Iowa.
He said, do you want to go along with us?
Well, I said, I will.
Oh, in the meantime, he had come along one day,
he said, look, he said,
I put in for a raise for you for 40 cents an hour,
and they turned it down at the head office.
I'm going to,
to plug enough times that you'll get 40 cents an hour.
He said, I'll plug your time.
He said, I like the way you work.
When to get back?
Well, I said, yeah, I'll go across Iowa,
but I don't think I should have to dig any more holes.
I said, I can dig more holes than anybody you've got around here.
It's time I learned something else about the business.
Well, he said, you won't have to.
He said, well, I'll start you out on,
on other work that you get to familiarize yourself with.
And I said, well, you've got to get out of the building of Lyons.
So when we got over to Homer, Nebraska,
just south of Sioux City, Iowa where we were working,
and there I started doing other things,
framing crossarms and helping set poles
and tamping poles and lining poles
and putting on crossarms.
And pretty soon we started string and wire.
I knew a little bit about climbing poles
because I'd fixed telephones at home.
So I started climbing poles, and that was the start of my career as a lineman.
This takes us into about the first of March, 1927.
It was spring down there. Spring broke up early.
There was no snow there by the first of March. Real mild weather.
And then one Sunday I took an ocean to drive up to see my brother Laurie up at Sioux Falls, South Dakota,
which is about 150 miles away.
And when I get up there, I found him in a terrible shape.
He had sciatica, and he had lost his wife the year before, and he had eight kids.
The oldest girl was about 17, and the oldest boy was about 13.
So...
Oh, he was in a terrible way. He could hardly walk.
Didn't know how he was going to get his crop in or anything.
So I said, I'll quit my job, and I'll come up and I'll put your crop in for you.
When I went back, I told the foreman I was going to quit, and I said,
I like this work, but I don't like the life that's with it.
I said, you're sort of a transient wherever you go.
I said, you're never in one place very long.
And I said, I think I better leave it right now and start doing something else.
Oh, he said, you'll leave it now, but you'll be back.
He said, I know you. You're the type. You'll be back.
So I went back up to Sioux Falls and took over, took charge of my brother's farm.
So I'll just rest for a minute now.
After a pause and taking a bit of a rest, I'll start in at my brother's farm.
Now, remember, I'm 25 years old.
I had run the home place for three years,
so I was pretty well prepared to take charge of almost anything that come along.
I had never worked on a corn farm, and this was strictly corn, cattle, and hogs.
So instead of driving a six- or eight-horse outfit here, you were driving a two- or a four.
And with his direction, I got everything done.
I planted the corn and checked the corn.
When you plant it, you have a wire that you string along, and it trips.
Every 36 inches, it trips the corn into the ground, but you have to keep that lined up
so that you can cultivate it both ways.
Everything went fine.
We got along good and had his crop all in, the corn cultivated and everything going fine.
And then July, all of a sudden, about the middle of July, here comes a hailstorm.
And it just knocked everything to pieces.
Well, he didn't know what to do.
It knocked the old crop down.
He had 40 acres of oats almost ready for the binder.
Well, I said, we'll call in the neighbors and mow her down, stack her up.
So I called in the neighbors.
We mowed down the 40 acres in a hurry and had the house stacked up and everything.
And now I'm finished.
In the meantime, I had been, while I was in Iowa, my cousin from Nebraska,
David City, Nebraska, said, when you're down in our part of the country,
come and see us.
So I had been in touch with them, and they said Harvest was coming on there.
Why didn't I come down and help them harvest?
So I did that.
I went down, and they were right in the throes of cutting the grain.
In those days, they still cut it with the binders, with horses and binders.
And we thrashed.
I was a stooker, setting up the stooks.
And when that was finished, well, we started then thrashing.
And the neighbors had an outfit, and I hauled bundles on that thrashing outfit.
Got all the crops thrashed.
Oh, there were some experiences like that that would make you smile
if you knew what that of an urinary bugger I was.
The guy, he wouldn't move the machine, and I was pitching in the dust all day long.
So I got mad in the afternoon, and I filled that machine so damn full of straw.
It took him an hour to clean it out.
And then he got mad at me.
He gave me hell.
I said, if you knew anything about an outfit, I could plug the machine.
Well, he said, if you know so much about it, let's see you set it that you can't plug it.
So I said, get me a pliers and a wrench, and I'll set her.
Well, I set it that you couldn't plug it.
Oh, hell.
The feeder wouldn't stop if it got coming in too fast.
Well, he never said anything until after I left.
It came back to me that he said,
I guess that guy did know something about a thrashing outfit.
Well, we finished there, and then I headed north.
I didn't know where I was going.
I stopped in at my brother's place in Sioux Falls.
And I had an uncle up near Aberdeen, South Dakota.
So I knew the oldest boy.
I'd met him in Iowa.
He was just my age.
So I went up there, and when I got up there, well, it was just haying time.
They were not in.
Well, they had been doing some harvesting.
Anyway, I said I was looking for a job.
I'd like to run the thrashing outfit.
This is what I was after.
So they turned me on to an outfit.
It was the best thrasher in the country.
So I drove up there, brave as hell, 25 years old, applied for the job.
Oh, he said, I'm sorry, I just engaged a fellow this afternoon.
On Saturday, we were running through some oats to have horse feed for the thrashers.
And come on up, anyway.
Well, I went up, and as it was, the other guy didn't turn up.
So we started thrashing, and we hadn't gone ten minutes, I don't think.
And all of a sudden, biffity-bang, and pieces started flying.
And part of the concave, that's the part that does the thrashing and the thrashing, and
the thrashing.
It was the thrashing in the front of the machine had broke loose and gone into the
blower, smashed up the blower and everything.
And he's a Scandinavian fellow.
He said, OK.
He said, you fix up the front end, I fix up the back end.
Well, I found out that they had overhauled the separator, and they hadn't set the concaves
right in it.
And one of them dropped out, had went through into the blower and bent things up badly
back there.
He got that all straightened out, and an hour and a half, we were thrashing again.
He come to me.
He said, I think we'll get along OK.
He says, you'll come back when we start thrashing.
You got the job.
Well, the wages were $10 a day.
Ten room and board, which is big money at that time.
Well, his brother ran the engine, and I ran the separator.
And we thrashed 12 hours a day, thrashing belt time.
He said, I don't want this machine to stop ever.
12 hours a day, I want it to be turning.
As long as the belts are turning, I get paid.
We thrashed, what was it, 29 out of 31 days.
We thrashed right through Sundays and all.
We got laid off twice for showers and rain.
And in that time, I only had an hour and a half lost time with the separator.
And the engineer, he had it for two hours last time.
Two hours last time with his engine.
That was about the last time we had thrashing 12 hours a day.
You ate lunch on the run.
In the mornings, you always had a lunch.
At noon, you stopped a half an hour for dinner.
In the afternoon, you had donuts and coffee again.
And then you thrashed right through until about 6.30 or 7 o'clock at night.
You had to do all your belt lacing and everything like that.
I hardly ever got to bed before midnight.
And at 4.30 in the morning, he was there calling again.
His call was, oh, I must relate that we slept in the barns.
And the bedding in your furnace was a horse blanket.
And you could make your own bed out of hay or however you wanted.
And my way of sleeping was right on the hard floor
with a little straw under my head for a pillow.
I'd take off all my clothes at night and shake them out.
I wore high-top boots.
Take them off.
Put everything back on excepting my high-top boots.
And lay down.
By the time you had slept, say, four and a half hours,
and he was, his call was, daylight in the swamp, boys.
And you were glad to get up after laying on the hard floor for four hours.
Well, that was the way I slept for a month.
Right on the hard floor.
No, just the horse blanket.
Laying on it and used half of it to cover me.
However, that season wound up.
I picked up my $300 or whatever it was.
And then I headed north.
Yeah, then I headed.
I was home since I was five.
I wanted to come to Canada and see the family.
So I come up to Canada to see the family.
Driving my Model T Ford.
And let me get ahead of myself now.
I have to stop right now.
Yeah, so I headed north for Canada.
I spent a couple of weeks up home.
And then driving back to South Dakota,
down to where my uncle lived at Frederick, out of Aberdeen, South Dakota.
I rode my car.
Went to sleep at the wheel.
I was driving straight through in the middle of the night.
About daylight in the morning, I rode my car.
The luckiest guy in the world.
Smashed all the glass in it.
And I never even got a bruise or a cut.
Well, I went into Valley City.
And I patched it up enough that I could drive another hundred miles down to my uncle's place.
And so while I was there, my cousin said,
Hey, there's a power gang working down here at Leola about 25 miles from there.
He said, They're building a power line in there.
Maybe we could get a job.
So he and I go on down there one afternoon.
And by again, I go in the hotel and talk to the foreman.
He's half drunk.
Told him what experience I had.
He said, You come to work Monday morning.
And I went to work.
Frank Wenner was his name.
A Finlander.
About five foot two.
And weighed about 180 pounds.
He reminded me of Uncle Wally for Bill.

He stayed in the hotel and stayed drunk and let the crew run their own.
He had a foreman that would run the crew.
Well, when we got from Leola, we went up to Frederick.
And I was acquainted with Frederick.
He was a great foreman.
He was a guy that ran the town.
And he used to keep me in about every second day to go out and buy him a bottle of whiskey.
Everything was homebrew.
The country was dry so you had to go out and buy bootleg liquor.
And he took a liking to me somehow.
And he's always favored me.
And from there we moved over into Dawson, North Dakota.
This is the middle of the winter.
Well, maybe about February.
and in Dawson, North Dakota. We were there building lines. He took pneumonia and died.
So they brought in another foreman, a fellow by the name of Bill Oberts.
And Bill was a quiet type of a guy. He didn't go out to the job much either. He relied on his
foreman bringing in reports to him. By this time, I'm pretty well recognized in the outfit now.
And I'm in with the linemen, the guys that are four or five linemen, and I was semi with them.
And we kept on going and going. And then we split up the crew and they get another foreman.
And this fellow, he took a liking to me. He's a younger man. And he taught me an awful lot

together and we built a heavy line from Thunderhawk, South Dakota, up to Elgin,

which was one of the top-notch jobs on the outfit, and had a lot of experience with that

went down there, and I
I had one man helping me and I cut the whole town over, which had to be done in sections.
You cut one section after the other and kept crowding the higher voltage behind you and cutting off the lower voltage sections
and cutting over all the transformers and everything as you went along. It was a good experience for me.
I finished that job and then he had to do an odd job throughout until January when an ad came in the paper that the Power Commission were hiring men.
And so I went to the superintendent and I said, look, I'm about finished here. I said, maybe I should apply for a job there.
He said, and I said, what would it mean if I called them? Well, he said, they'll be here long after we're gone.
He said, the government's gone.
The government starts taking over, they'll take over.
So I came to each other.
Well, I wrote him. Wrote him, that's right.
And I wrote him and asked for a job and forgot all about it.
I grew up out of town. I had run into a pretty nice schoolmarmie out in the country.
And I was out visiting her.
And I didn't know where she lived.
I went to this small town to phone to see where she was at.
While I was there, the telephone operator said to me, are you Lindy Achen?
I said, yes.
Well, she said, they've been trying to get a hold of you from Estevan.
Well, I hadn't told her so that I was going out.
But the telephone operators in those days, it wasn't automatic like it is today.
The telephone operators kept very close track of what was going on when the long distance company from Regina.
They had heard me phone this girl when I was coming out.
And so they phoned the operator there and said, if Lindy Achen is in the district there any place, trace her down.
And they had swarmed out to where this girl was teaching.
And I wasn't there.
However, I get on the phone.
I thought, back to reach out to this number.
And here.
Here's the superintendent up in Regina here.
He wants me to come in in two days.
They're hiring five men and I was one of the five.
And they put us through a fast two-day course of the book work and everything.
And then with our service work.
And I was posted to Saskatoon, which was a Class B district.
My wages were $155 a month.
I had my own car.
And I used my car on the job.
And I got 10 cents a mile for driving, for using my own vehicle.
When I was up there, many things happened.
The superintendent was a young, green superintendent.
He didn't know anything about power lines.
Just out of university.
So he relied a lot on me for information whenever there was trouble and whatnot.
And I worked there about four months.
He was pretty impressed with the job that I was doing.
And the man that they had sent to the Class I district at Rosetown was a university graduate.
But he got down there and he really got things mixed up.
So my superintendent said to me one day,
How would you like to be transferred to Rosetown?
I said, If I get his wages, yes, I will.
So I go down there and I knew the fellow.
He had got into the battle quite a bit.
He wasn't paying attention to his job.
And he had everything mixed up.
Well, I took over Rosetown.
More or less took charge of things.
Well, I had my district there.
I had eight towns to look after.
And they had all been built in the wintertime.
And everything was hanging crooked and leaning crooked.
So as I had spare time, I'd hire a kid and help me.
And got this all straightened out.
And then one day I got a letter from the superintendent eating me out.
As the superintendent, eating me out for hiring help without authority.
I was paying these kids 30 cents an hour.
Doing a good job.
We got a lot of work done.
Then when he saw what a job I had been doing in the towns,
then he turned around and made all the other district men do what I had been doing.
Well, along with that and a few other things that happened,
I was young.
Young and what would you say?
Young and free and wild.
I had money in the bank.
I had bought a brand new car while I was there.
So I said I wanted to leave with absence.
That was about the end of September.
Wanted to leave of absence for three months.
Oh, we don't have such a thing in the books.
Well, I said I'll take it off and take my own chances of getting back to work when I get back.
So okay.
So okay.
I check out.
When I came to Regina, I stopped at the head office.
The head superintendent said,
Boy, you've done an ace high job for us.
He says,
We have nothing but praise for the work that you've done.
But we can't guarantee that you'll have a job when you come back in the spring.
Things are getting tougher all the time.
This is in the spring of 1931.
No, in the fall of 1931.
And anyway, away I go.
I go down to Hallbright, Mydale.
Mack was living in Mydale.
Brother Mack was living in Mydale.
Mydale wanted to put in a power plant.
And they said,
You're just the guy to come down here and put in our distribution system for us.
I said,
I want to take my mother down to Iowa for a month first.
Well, that'll be plenty of time.
You get back here in November.
That'll be plenty of time.
So my mother and I went to Iowa.
And I had a week of time down in Iowa with all the relatives.
And I had been down there on a visit twice before that.
So I knew a lot.
When I come back, I went down to Mydale and put in the distribution system.
Got that done.
Then all the houses and stores had to be wired.
So my brother Mack and I spent the winter there wiring up these houses and stores.
And making money all the time, you know.
Well then, the job is finished.
It's spring.
So about in May, I wander out through John O'Hare and go into the Power Commission.
See if I can get a job.
Well, if I can get a job, we're still laying off men.
Things are that tough that we're still laying off men.
We're not hiring them.
And the superintendent got nasty with me then.
The guy that had praised me so much when I checked out.
He said,
Oh, that's the kind of a guy you are.
You go and pick an inside job for the winter and now you come back in the summer and want a job.
Well, he'll never know how close I come to climbing over his desk and punching him in the nose.
But I held myself and walked out of his office.
And I went back to the farm and left around all summer.
Having a good time.
Helping on the farm, of course.
That fall, we didn't have much harvest.
And we got our own work done up early with our own help.
Just Bud and my cousin, Tad, and a few of us.
We put our little thrashing outfit to work.
We got the harvest off of them.
There were others around the country that wanted to get thrashing done.
So Bud hired me and the separator out.
These guys would have a tractor.
And I'd run the outfit.
And for that, he was getting $4 an hour or $40 a day for this separator.
And myself and the farmer in front of the tractor.
And I would run both hands.
But I don't know what he was paying me.
A couple bucks a day.
Oh, we must have gotten more than $4 an hour.
But he was paying me $2 or $3 a day.
And he probably got $7 or $8 for the outfit.
And I worked there.
And maybe three weeks doing that.
And then I got in the car.
In the meantime,
in June, Dominion Electric knew I wasn't working.
They phoned me.
I went down there and worked for two weeks.
They had the job they wanted done.
I went and worked for two weeks.
So I went back in the fall.
And Bud said, I can put you to work.
He said, we've got some work here.
So I worked in Estevan for about the month of October
with the gang that was there.
And then they were putting in a power plant out of Hopkins.
It was the nearest power plant.
So they put them in another.
They put them in another isolated plant,
a little diesel plant.
And he said, I want you to go out there
and build the distribution system.
And I knew the fellow was going to go out there
and put the plant in.
They were setting up this small company.
And he was leaving them.
He was a seam engineer from Estevan.
He was leaving them and going out
to set up this small plant.
Get on his own.
I go out there and I put in the distribution system.
Oh, it was a beautiful fall.
We went out there in November.
There was snow on the ground.
But it all went away.
And it was like summer until the middle of December.
And they got the plant going about the 17th of December.
Well, in that winter, I wired, built houses and stores
in that town all winter.
So I was busy making a living.
And that was about all.
Then the next spring, my old company, Dominion Electric,
you boys hired me to go into Gull Lake.
There was some bad wiring jobs.
And they couldn't meter it properly in three or four places
in Gull Lake, business places.
So I went in and I straightened all that out.
When I got that finished, he took me up to Bigger, Saskatchewan.
It's up by Saskatoon.
There I did the hospital and three, four stores
that had messes in the wiring.
And got it all straightened out.
And then I come back to Gull Lake.
And I started overhauling the distribution system.
And I worked there about three, four years.
Three months in the summer.
All by myself.
I would have a helper for a half a day.
And that was all.
The rest of the time, I was by myself.
And doing jobs that normally I'd put two or three men at.
When I finished that, I went down to the town of East End.
I just had another small decent time.
And I worked there for a month.
All of a sudden, New York, who owned the Dominion Electric power,
said,
cut all spending.
That's the end of it.
We can't spend any more money this year.
So I get a phone call to shut her down right then.
I was one-man crew again.
I could shut her down pretty easy.
But while I was there, I lined up a lot of wiring jobs.
So I wired for a month in East End.
I had enough work to carry me on for a month.
And then I went back up to Tompkins,
where this friend of mine was running the power plant.
And I tucked in there for the winter.
You'd get room and board for about a dollar and a half a day,
is what it would cost you to live.
And played cards.
Did some wiring around there that winter, odd jobs.
And then in the spring,
oh, yeah, then the next year I went out
and I ran a crew for the Dominion Electric.
He hired me.
Dominion Electric hired me back here.
And I went down.
I overhauled the power line from Shaunavon to Assiniboine.
It's 120 miles.
We climbed every pole on that line
and repaired everything that needed repairing.
I had three men and myself.
And we worked hard.
It was a hot, dry summer.
But we kept on plugging.
And we were working six and seven days a week.
What was I getting then?
I was getting, I think,
$0.50 an hour.
We worked a nine-hour day.
So I'd make it $4.50 a day.
And you could get room and board for a couple dollars a day.
I worked there until,
oh, yeah, we hadn't finished the job
when they shut her down again.
They got out of money.
So back to Tompkins I go again.
My pal was,
this time he was getting pretty dissatisfied.
Sitting in there watching that little 40-horse diesel
chug away.
Turning over 300 revolutions.
A minute.
And he was having trouble with it.
But he was not a good operator.
He never fixed anything before it broke.
Put it that way.
So I saw he was dissatisfied.
And I asked him one day if he wanted to sell out.
Yeah, he said,
I'd be glad to get the hell out of here.
So I phoned Estevan and told him about it.
And they were glad to get rid of him.
They weren't happy with him as an operator.
So they said,
you go ahead and make the deal.
And then tell us what you worked up.
And I told them.
And they gave me the money to swing the deal.
I traded my car in.
I borrowed $600 from my mother.
And here I was president of Tompkins Electric.
Well, I was without transportation.
So in Dominion Electric,
my old superintendent saw that.
He said,
we've got a half-ton truck standing down in the yard there.
It's not in good running order.
But you'll make it run.
So they sent that up.
And I had that half-ton truck.
And I drove in the power plant.
Well, then my brother, Mac,
was out of work in Estevan.
So he'd come up.
He and his wife,
they moved up.
And then right away,
he learned how to run the power plant.
There was nothing left.
Well, then I was free to go out and do wiring.
I did odd jobs for Dominion Electric
around the country.
They'd whistle me out to do a job.
I went to different towns
that work among other kinds.
I wasn't making any money.
My salary when I run the power plant
was $75 a month.
And that's all the plant could afford.
It just barely paid its way,
paid interest and fuel and wages.
$75 a month.
Well, I operated that
for about a year and a half.
And then the company saw fit
to build a line from Gull Lake to Tompkins
and shut that down.
We're into 1930.
We're into 1930.
Yeah, I operated the plant
35, 36 and into the spring of 37.
And as soon as I heard
they were going to build the plant,
I said, or build that line,
I said, I'll build that line for you.
I'll give you a price on it.
So I got busy and figured out
where I could hire trucks and things.
And then the superintendent come down
and said, I'll build that line
for $285 a mile.
He said, you think you can do it for that?
I said, I know I can.
And I'll make money at it.
And the next time he come back
a couple of weeks later, he said,
I can't give you that job.
He said, the diesel superintendent's
son-in-law is a contractor
and he's been out of work for three years.
He wants to give it to him.
But he said, you can work on the job.
You'll be his foreman while he's here.
Well, I went out.
I do a hell of a lot of work.
He had a crew of about 12 men
and I was bossing around.
He wasn't much of an operator,
I found that out.
When I got that,
oh yeah, in the meantime,
this fellow that I took the plant over from
had gone up to Gotham, Manitoba
and got a job running a steam plant up there.
While he was there, he found out
there's a little town
that went up to Gosis, Manitoba
that needed a power plant.
And he right away makes a deal
with them to put in power
and he didn't have any money.
So he comes hollering to me.
He said, can you help me out?
He said, I'm in trouble.
I have a franchise here
and I can't fulfill it.
Well, hell, I didn't have any money.
So I phoned down to the general manager
of the Dominion Electric,
told him the story.
Oh, he said, we'll pull him out.
So they go up and take a look at it.
They take over the franchise.
And then they said,
we're going to put you up there.
There's no wiring in the town.
There isn't a power of any kind in town.
There's about 120 places to wire up.
Put you up there to wire up the town.
Not to build the power lines.
This son-in-law deal,
he was going to build the power lines,
but I was going to wire the building.
I went up there in June
and my brother Max followed me up
in about two weeks.
Everything was closed down in Tompkins.
And they were moving that plant
up to Enopecosis.
Well, I had nothing to do with the plant.
All I did was wire the stores and houses.
My brother Max and I worked up there.
In the month of September,
they needed me down in Escalante for a month.
My brother Max had a helper,
and he came wiring.
I went down to Escalante
for distribution, the mines and everything.
For a month.
While that guy went out
and looked over another job,
he was moving into a different field.
The guy that was the operator.
So, then I come back up to Enopecosis
and I wound up there on Armistice Day.
And I walked out of there
with everything cut and dried.
I had a little box full of material left,
and I sent it back to the wholesaler
at Winnipeg,
and they paid me back 75% on the dollar,
what it was worth.
I walked out with $1,200,
in my pocket,
after living all summer,
and buying a second-handed V8 Ford,
which turned out to be a kind of a lemon,
after a while.
But when I went back to Escalante,
I was back to Escalante by the end of,
well, the middle of November.
Then I took over the distribution,
operating, servicing all the mines,
and, and,
and the town.
And that was in the fall of 37.
And in the spring of 38,
I went out and relieved out at Gravelbourg in La Flesche,
while they changed operators out there.
And in the fall of 38,
I was sent out to Shawnevan
and Gravelbourg to calibrate meters.
Oh, I'd gone about two weeks on that,
and then come back to Escalante again.
And then I kept on working in Escalante
until,
until I was married.
Oh yeah, the war broke out in the fall of 38.
And they were building an airport,
and that is all.
And I worked there 38, 39.
Fall of 40, we were married.
And I said 41, 42, 43, 44,
on call, 24 hours a day,
30 days a month,
when I got holidays.
I don't think I took help,
and that was all.
And then, then,
to get back to the story again,
by this time, Dominion Electric were
getting pretty big up in the Peace River Company.
The superintendent was spending a lot of time up there.
And they blew up a big generator down at the power plant.
And they tore it all apart,
got it opened up so that you could see
what had burned out on the wiring end of it.
And Schlosser, the general manager,
he didn't know how to put that into words
to send a telegram to,
to New York to tell them,
what had happened and what was necessary.
So he asked me to go down and take a look at it.
And then we went back up to the office
and drafted a telegram to New York
to tell them what was involved in that.
It was going to be a lengthy lay,
a shutdown.
And then after we had sent the telegram,
this was about 9 o'clock at night,
we were sitting in the office,
and I said, I see where the
the Power Corporation, or the Power Commission,
at that time,
are advertising for a bunch of lines
they're going to build.
In fact, they're building,
tearing down airport lines
at Midale and Halbrite,
all in through there,
and building up into power lines
in those small towns.
I said, I got a damn good notion
to bid on that.
I said, I know how to build power lines
if anybody does.
He said, why don't you?
He said, I'll give you a leave of absence
if you don't get any work.
He said, you can come back to work again.
Well, I went with them.
Two days later, they were opened.
There were four bidders,
and they were all older men
that had been contracting power lines
when the Depression came up.
It was in 28, 29, and 30.
And now, 15 years later,
they're still sitting there
with all their tools and equipment
and nothing had happened
for 15 years, you might say.
And these guys were all in there bidding,
and I'm in there bidding.
I'm the kid bidder.
These fellas are all 15, 20 years older than I am.
Well, they opened up the tenders,
and it was one of the most amazing things
that you ever saw.
The tenders range, now this is in 1945 dollars.
You can multiply that by nine for today.
But they,
they first tender opened up,
Next one, $11,500.
The next one,
And then mine was the last one,
Well, here I was just
right in the ballpark.
Those guys, I'll bet you any money
that they went to that grade
thinking that I had an inside tip-off.
But the amazing part of it was that
we all did it in such close range,
and it was really a complicated job.
You had to take up thousands and thousands of feet
of underground cable that was buried
two feet under the ground,
and you were supposed to take it up without damaging it.
And tearing down all these little power lines,
and there was telephones and power
and everything mixed up.
And then using that same material,
or what was usable,
build a power line,
well, in one case from Macoun to Halbrite,
and
we were all bidding that close.
It was almost impossible to think
that four men could sit down individually
and come up within a thousand dollars
from top to bottom.
Anyway,
away I go.
Then a little later,
they bid on a line from
Spelt to Esplanade,
and this was the first high voltage
suspension type line in the province.
None of us had ever bid on it.
And only the one guy that was
his son-in-law
that I referred to.
And myself
was the only two bidders.
And he bid $600 a mile,
and I bid $550.
Today you pay about $3,000
a mile for that same type of line.
Anyway, I got it.
Now I'm in business science.
That line
wasn't to be started
until the next year.
But I worked. I tore down the airports,
and I got the line going from
Halbrite to Midale.
And then part of it to
Macomb.
Well then again I started firing.
I didn't make another guy
to wire, and I kept him
going all winter at Midale.
I went to Esteban and really
didn't do much of anything.
Tore the way around all winter.
And getting ready for the next spring.
And then the next spring
is when I had to wrestle
some equipment and get going on my own.
And that time
I hired
a truck.
No, I went and I bought a half-ton truck.
A half-ton is six, seven years old.
And I'd been on the cream route
pretty well down there,
but it served my purpose.
When I need the heavier truck,
I rent it.
But I rented a man with a truck.
So then I...
Oh yeah, that fall, that's right.
There's some army trucks
that came for sale up in Regina.
And I come up and I bought a
truck and a gun carrier.
That was a useful thing.
Four-wheel drive.
You could go any place with it.
And put a boom on it
for setting poles.
And then the next spring
I bought another truck.
In fact, I bought two trucks
the next spring.
And then I started and got going.
And yeah,
I forgot, the fall of 45
when I finished the airport,
I came in to reach out of here and did some work.
And I found out about
a new building development.
The first one in Regina
for 20 years, I guess.
And this was for returned soldiers.
And after I put the distribution system in there,
that was in December and January.
And then in February I went up to Saskatoon
and they had the same thing up there.
And I went up and did that one.
And then it was getting into
towards spring.
And then the old Dominion Electric
had some work to do at Craigton-Davidson.
So I went down there
for the spring break up.
And then I went back to
Estevan.
I was still living in Estevan at this time.
Went back to Estevan and started
all my power line jobs
and my contract.
And really never looked back.
From that day on it was work.
There was always work ahead.
I was never out of work.
I would lay off in the wintertime.
Lay off Christmas until
maybe March
or April.
And then I went up small.
By the time the snow was all gone
and the fields were dry
you would build up your full crew.
So it was an interesting
part of the contracting
was that start-up period.
I started out with men.
I didn't have a man that knew anything
about line work.
And I finally got a hold of a
lineman.
A little fellow.
He was only about five foot six
with a hell of a line.
He had his own name.
He agreed enough to get by.
And then I
the next thing I
in about a month's time I picked up Art Miller.
Art came.
He was sent to me by
he had come to the power here to get work
and they didn't need men.
They sent him to me.
And he had signed some telephone
posts in his day that
he wasn't much
you couldn't write him as a lineman
but he was real good at drugs.
I had a good man to move
their trucks and to look after them
and see that they were running.
And then from there on you hire
nothing but kids. Guys 18 years old.
They know nothing from nothing
and you train them.
But I saw with these young guys
at that time you could
give them a kick in the rear end if they needed
and pat them on the shoulder the next
half hour and tell them what a good job
they were doing.
And they worked for you.
They turned out a lot of good men.
Come back to me after all you were tough
but you sure taught us a lot
while we worked for you.
It's one of those things
that you just keep going.
One of the biggest
thrills was going out with a bunch
of young guys and training them.
As your crew got bigger and you couldn't
be out with them all the time
I always missed that. I always loved
working with a bunch of men.
And I knew how to get work
out of them.
Once in a while you'd have a guy that
wouldn't come up to standard.
You'd have to let him go.
There was an awful lot of shovel work
in those days.
You could always break a guy in
and get him hardened.
You'd hire a guy to come out.
He'd never done any work in his life
and get him a shovel and start
to dig an anchor hole.
And you'd think it's an impossibility.
You'd spend an hour with him
and show him how to use the tools
and in a couple of days you've got
a good man. He hardens in fast.
But if he sits down for five minutes
he's up and going again.
And that's just about
our last art today.
There is no more shovel work.
You hire a guy today and you've got
to put him on a big machine
if you're almost afraid to let him.
We're talking now
the end of 1945 and 1946.
46, yes.
I built that big line to South 46.
Besides doing
many odd jobs.
I took the line out of Regina
down to the new radio stations
six, eight miles south.
And I did some work
for the city.
And I finished that line
on the 9th of December.
That big line.
That was an experience.
And I had to do everything on my own.
You had no place to go
to ask for information.
You had to rig up all your own equipment.
But we'd come out of it.
Made some money on it.
All my diggers,
they went on the strike.
They were about a third of the way
up that line.
They kept asking for more money.
They wanted piece work.
So one day I heard there was
a boring machine in Winnipeg
and I jumped on the train
and I went in and I bought
a brand new boring machine.
It was the second one to come
into Saskatchewan.
And from there on I had the diggers
behind the ball.
We finished that job
on the 9th of December.
I remember that so well.
And then I laid only for the winter.
Didn't do anything all winter
until the next spring.
And then we had to tender
about early April.
I got some work
building a line from Weyburn
to Radville about 30 miles.
We started on that
in the early spring.
We finished that.
We did some farms around Weyburn.
That was in 46.
No, that was 47.
That's right, 47.
And after that
I got a job up at
a big job up at
the Rosetown
area.
I got a hundred and some miles
with eight or ten towns
to build on.
That was the summer's work.
And I built up a crew
and got them going
and then the power come along
and six towns up there
and about 50 miles
of line to build.
That was really stretching myself a bit
when I took that on.
I had to leave my crew at Rosetown
and go over and start up another crew
out of the blue
at Yorkton.
And that was
going through bush country.
That was a new experience for us.
Had to cut the slough
through the bush
where you're going to build a line.
A 25-foot slough
through these trees.
And they're trees up to 40 feet high.
Well, you could get a lot of labor

I set up the terms under which I wanted to sell the business to the man, and I was not
for selling to a partnership, it had to be a company, and Art Miller was to be at the
head of it, which meant he had to own 51% of the shares, and there were Bill Zaharachuk,
Ron Canaday, and George Jenny were coming in as minority partners.
And they all agreed to that, they were all willing to just take a chunk with it.
They all knew Art and knew that he knew how to run the business, etc.
So they went ahead on that basis, and everything was going fine.
Things never looked any better for contracting.
The government had changed from the NDP to a liberal.
And liberals were for contracting out work, rather than doing it with government crews.
So when I sold out, I said to the boys, it never looks so good, but I said, I'm finished,
I'm burned out, I'm getting out of here right now, after 20 years, I said, I've had it.

I gave them a good deal, I didn't hijack them, hold them up for it or anything.
