It was interesting to see how we could take this old junk and make it work.
And that was part of our success was to keep the overhead down.
A friend of mine actually asked me one time how much I spent on boring machines.
And I told him we had four machines at that time.
He said, we spend more than that on one machine in a year.
Well, I said, you haven't got the operators.
You've got to have the right men operating it and, of course, overhauling it as well.
So that gives you an idea of what you run into for equipment.
I went over the SaskPower.
I went over to the finance.
I may have told you something about that in the start.
But throughout the years, I never had any trouble financing.
I think I told you I had $3,000 in the bank when I started.
And I went to the bank manager in Estevan and told him I might need a little extra money.
And he said, well, how much you got?
I said, I got $3,000 in bonds in the safety deposit box.
I said, you want me to put them up for collateral?
He said, you go ahead.
And he said, I'll just run you on overdrafts until I charge you interest on it.
In those days, they allowed you to run on overdrafts.
With the result that I never had a sign of any description.
I operated out of Estevan from 45 and then 48 when I came up here to Regina.
I said to the fellow in the bank, there's one thing I want understood now when we start.
I don't understand.
I never want one of my checks turned down.
There isn't enough money in the bank to cover it.
You cover it until I get there to take care of it.
And I said, if you don't, I'll move my account to Moose Jaw where my old friend,
Bill Mullins, who started me up in Estevan, is the manager at Moose Jaw.
And he'll take care of me.
Well, I never did have a check turned down on overdraft, no matter.
One time, I was overdrawn about $10,000.
And there was a relief manager in.
And he called me and he said, hey, your account's getting pretty badly overdrawn.
He said, I think we'd better take a look at that.
I said, what are you worrying about that for?
I said, I think I've got to worry about that.
He didn't know that at that particular time, I had about $30,000 worth of work done,
which I hadn't invoiced, which would wipe out the $10,000 in a hurry.
And he said, I don't know.
One time in the spring of the year, I needed quite a bit of money,
and I give them the $5,000 government bond for security.
There was another manager come in, and he was a little shaky.
So I put that up until I had my overdraft taken care of.
And then I forgot that they had it, and that fall when I went in to get it,
I thought I'd better cash it in.
And here I'd run overtime and had to take a penalty
for not cashing it in.
On the due date, I don't think they have that anymore.
So I always got along well with financing, never had any trouble.
I could complete a job and then invoice the power corporation for it.
Evidently, all the other contractors were always,
when they'd get a couple weeks' work done, they'd invoice on it, invoice on it.
Ted Durnan, the superintendent, said to me one day,
he said, I think you're making too damn much money.
I said, why do you say that?
Well, he said, all the other guys are subbing all the time, and you're not.
Well, I said, I'm working for the same price they're working.
But I said, I've got news for you.
My credit is good enough at the bank that I could build lines all summer
and invoice you for it in the fall.
And I said, so it's not that I'm making too much money,
but I said, I've got a good credit established.
Wow.
So we went along.
Oh, in 1954, they had a big sleet storm in Manitoba,
and they took down all the telephone lines in southern Manitoba.
And they come to Saskatchewan for help,
see if we could rig up some small three-man crews on half-ton trucks.
So they came to me, and I don't know how they got a hold of my name,
and asked how many outfits I could send out, three-man crews.
They would supervise them once they got out there.
So I phoned all the contractors, and I lined up 12 outfits.
This was early in the spring, about early May or the end of April.
Between all the contractors, I lined up 12 outfits.
Two of my own were in that.
Well, then I found out how the guys were operating.
Most of them had me sub them for money to buy a license before they could get going.
And I paid them.
I paid them.
Every two weeks, I paid them out for their units.
And I didn't get any money until the whole job was finished.
And when it was finished, it came to, I think it was $38,000.
And I invoiced the government telephones in Manitoba for that much money.
And that was the biggest check I had ever received up to that date.
I didn't know how much I should charge, take off, for supervising the operation.
So I took 10%.
That's what I got for it.
And it was all over in, I think our outfits were down there maybe three weeks or something like that.
So I got paid $3,800 for my three weeks.
And it was all office work as far as I was concerned.
Telephoned a lot of people.
Telephone calls.
And what were some of the other highlights?
I told you about the last job I did, which was the biggest individual job I had ever bid on,
which was just under $200,000.
I made some money on it, but didn't get wealthy on it, to put it that way.
And I don't know.
All in all, it was interesting.
I have told you before that Ted Durnan tried to hire me one time to run their whole construction outfit.
That was in 1949.
He asked me what I'd take.
And I said, I'd take $10,000 a year, but there'd be no contracting.
And as long as there was contracting, I wanted to be in on the competitive field.
And he said, hell, I can't pay you $10,000 a year.
I only get $8,000.
I said, I figure I'm worth $10,000 to run your construction outfit.
That was my experience.
So that was the end of that.
They set up a different arrangement.
I think Jack Bell was sort of put in charge of the construction.
They never looked back.
They got so big at that time that money was nothing to them.
They just kept on expanding and expanding and expanding.
Until the union got a hold of it.
And all of a sudden they got in a squeeze where the union was running the outfit and said it themselves.
I've had them come to me when they had trouble.
Or not trouble, but they had a customer just out of Regina here that had to have service just at Christmas time.
They'd come to me, and that's why I couldn't rustle up a crew to go out and do this job.
It would take maybe four, five, or six days.
And then that came Christmas Day, Boxing Day.
And the same thing.
Sunday and all.
And they wanted to go out and work right straight through until it was finished.
I said, that's going to cost you a lot of money.
A lot of overtime in there for the amount of work we do.
That don't make any difference.
But when I present them with a bill, oh, we can't stand that overtime.
No way.
The engineer in charge said, if I presented that, my job could be on the line.
And he said, you're going to have to cut back and stand half that overtime yourself.
Which meant that I made damn little on the job.
But that's the way.
They would take advantage of you occasionally when they got you over the barrel.
All in all, I will have to say they treated me pretty fair.
I had a lot of leeway with them.
And with this man Durnan, we had a lot of trust in each other.
Although he was a tight one.
Boy, he wouldn't...
He'd give you authority to do things, but don't ever try to pad the invoice or anything.
Or he'd be right on you in a minute.
But it all went on and on.
While that was going on, I think I related earlier that I had an outfit working in the city for ten years.
Equipment, a boring machine, a pole truck, a pole trailer, and a two-ton truck.
And they were on so much an hour.
And in those ten years, I never raised the rate on that.
I only raised wages as they went along.
I took ten hours.
Ten percent on payroll.
Well, that was sort of a meal ticket for me.
And then when they'd get behind, I could leave the work stack up and bring in my men from the field in the fall when they were finished out there.
And then they would pick up a lot of extra work in the city.
I set all the poles in all the suburbs that were built from 1951.
Yes, I even did some in 1945 or 46.
And then...
I started again in 1950.
Set all the poles and built all the lines in all the suburbs in Regina that takes in Lakeview, Albert Park, Whitmore Park, Douglas Park, Norman...
What's the one up northwest?
Not Normanview.
Yeah, we did that too.
We did everything until...
As long as it was overhead, we were doing it.
Once it started going underground, then they started putting their own outfits in.
And then we were also involved in that through the years.
But not in a big way.
But for ten years, I had this deal with Nichols.
And the superintendent phoned me up one day and asked me what I would take to do some work for them.
And I quoted him over the telephone.
He said, put that out in a letter and send it to me.
And I sent it to him.
And about seven years later, he phoned back.
He said, hey, have you got anything, a copy of the deal we made when you started working for the city?
I said, yeah, I've got the letter in the file here somewhere.
And he said, I wish you'd send me a copy of it.
I can't find my copy of the letter.
I've been asked some questions regarding your work in here.
And he said, I want to show it to them that we had a contract.
And that was that until it finally petered out gradually.
And that was, boy, it was a sort of a mail ticket for me through those ten years.
I always had that steady work coming in in the city.
It wasn't big, but it took up the slack, so to speak.
It was a steady income.
And what were some of the other things?
Well, I'll have to just think for a moment of other things that may be of interest to you fellows.
Oh, yes.
Speaking of some of the lives of the game.
They always said a business, a company can't stay in business unless they expand.
Well, we virtually broke that law.
We never really expanded.
Well, after the first five years I expanded a bit and then went static from there.
I had a basic crew.
We had a building office.
We had a shop in 53 and it was too small the day I built it.
And it's still operating.
Now we're up to 35 years later and still getting along with that same shop.
I did put an extension on the office.
I expanded the office in 1958, I think it was.
Made some storage room upstairs.
And more office space in front which gave us more room in the shop.
But again, we broke the law that you can't operate.
Art took over and I figured right away he's going to have to move into bigger quarters.
But up until this day they're still making that same shop do the job.
I guess the proof in the pudding is the observation of it.
The company's always been silent financially and making money and making things do.
That's the biggest thing.
I've seen these shops, you know, with five or six stalls in them.
The Power Corporation were that way.
They'd have five or six stalls and everything standing there and nothing happening.
And when they wanted something overhauled they'd come down and say,
Can you get this ready for us tomorrow?
We've got to have this trenching machine going tomorrow.
And my fellows would run in the shop and Gwen and I would work on it.
We'd work on it all night and have it going for them.
And their shop, everything was standing still.
Well, they were unionized.
The guy that turned and cracked the wrench, he couldn't jack the vehicle up, so to speak.
Nobody ever knew what it cost them to do their repair work.
It was so extensive they never even kept track of it.
That was one of the rules of the game that we built.
So when Art and the boys took over,
they thought now they're going to show the old man how to run an outfit.
Do you know that they never changed one thing?
The same principles still apply after 21 years that were being used when I was there.
Excepting I had an old man for a bookkeeper.
When he died I got another old man.
Art got George Jenny's wife.
She had taken a business course.
She came in and she was a crackerjack of a bookkeeper.
She is worth her weight in gold.
I said, if I'd had one like that, maybe I wouldn't have quit business.
Because she really took a lot of load off in the office.
And Art put in a...
He was always a great guy for gadgets.
He put in a second-handed computer costing $1,500.
He would use it for payroll.
For keeping track of accounts and one thing or another.
And then after that he got rid of that and he put one in for $10,000.
But I still kid them.
I said, why do you have to have a computer?
I said, I had a man 80 years old making the payroll.
Doing all the books.
Everything was always up to date.
He'd be a little late if I asked for a cutoff to see how we were doing.
Sometimes it would take him 30 days to give me a cutoff.
But I questioned if they could do it any faster.
I said, I'd like to watch it with a computer.
But Art liked gadgets.
And he got computers.
He even got a small one in his bedroom at home.
And he does a lot of fiddling around with that.
He was one of the men with more ability than anybody I've probably ever run across.
He could do anything.
He could overhaul anything.
He could fix anything.
If they had hydraulic trouble on any machines,
even the competitors would bring their machines in and have him fix the hydraulics on them,
which sometimes, when you get a lot of hydraulics on a machine, it can become pretty tricky.
And while anything, diagnose anything, motor troubles or anything like that,
he could pick it off just like a real expert.
A computer, he could program a computer.
He did all his own programming.
And the computers were...
Most outfits hire a guy to come and do that art.
He said, I know what I want.
And he would program the computer.
And he said or claimed that prices changed so much
that unless you had a computer to keep track of it,
that you couldn't keep up to it, doing it in longhand.
Because when you're buying equipment and reselling it,
and buying repairs,
you can't keep track of your repairs.
But I question very much another girl.
Of course, if you're going to spend $15,000 for a computer,
or have to spend that much for another girl,
you might as well have a computer
and let a computer do the work if you can.
And that's another thing that in the computer age,
I guess you've got to go with it, whether you like it or not.
I get a kick out of it when I go down to buy a cup of coffee.
And to watch what a performance the girl goes through
to ring up a 55-cent cup of coffee,
and how that machine has to work.
And she punches buttons like playing a Hammond organ
to ring up a cup of coffee.
And I said, is all that necessary?
Well, it's got to go through the computer, she says.
I suppose they know exactly how much they make on a cup of coffee.
And that could be important if you're selling enough cups.
Well, now that it's all over,
I reminisce in my mind some of the things that happened in the past years.
I made a lot of friends in the business,
a lot of business friends in Regina.
And how fast now in 20 years,
or it's going on to 22 years,
it's all disappearing,
going over in the horizon.
Your friends are dying off.
They're moving away.
Things are...
What shall we say?
Retirement isn't what you imagined it would be.
It's all been a different life altogether than I thought it would be.
I thought we old-timers that were in the business
would be getting together and we'd have coffee.
You know that there's not one power man
that I have coffee with.
I have coffee with telephone guys,
and farmers,
and bookkeepers,
and railroaders,
but not one of the old power men around here anymore.
If they are,
they don't show up for coffee.
Oh, once in a while you'll meet one,
but not the old pals that I had.
I think I mentioned earlier
that my real close friends,
Jack Bell,
Harold Huntington,
and Al Wakemore.
Harold and Al died long ago,
and Jack Bell has moved up to Allentown.
So,
those were my real close friends.
And many of my other good friends
that I had in business
that lived down in the area where I am,
they've passed on.
There's not many of them around.
A fellow called me the other day
that I used to have coffee with regularly.
I hadn't seen him for,
I guess,
for 15 years.
He said,
we've got to get together some day and have coffee.
I said,
yeah,
he had a business right back to back.
Our business places were back to back
for 15 years.
But,
it's all changed,
all different.
You have to adjust,
sort of live from
week to week,
month to month,
and year to year.
Change,
accept what comes,
make the most of it.
One thing that I can say is that
I've enjoyed relatively good health.
I haven't been outside of my operation
a year ago,
a little over a year ago.
I've enjoyed relatively good health,
considering that when I quit,
when I quit in 1965,
I was pretty well burned out.
I didn't have any more giddy up
and go in me.
And that's why I got out of the business.
I said,
it's too tough
to come down here every day
and keep this outfit going.
While I was making good money,
I said,
if I don't get out of here,
you'll carry me out in a basket.
I've never regretted that.
But I got out when I did,
and I've never regretted that.
In fact,
I'm glad that the boys have done well
and kept the thing going.
And the name Achen
is still on the building,
which to me was
one of the highlights,
that they thought enough of me
to use the name.
We had a good reputation,
and they said,
can we use the name?
They asked for permission,
and I said,
yes, I'll grant you the permission
to use the name.
No strings attached,
except when they made it
Achen Construction 1965 Limited.
They just changed the name that much.
And they never even noticed
that the changeover took place.
Those are some of the good things
that come back to you.
I have to mention
the high praise I have
for the men that worked for me,
the key men that I kept around there.
There were six, eight of them.
They were working for me
all the time,
and that's what made the company go.
And this man Miller,
he was an oddball in some ways.
He was just ace high
as an employee.
He was a guy
that never said no.
In the 20 years
that we worked together,
I never raised my voice to him,
and he never raised his voice to me.
If we had any discussions,
they were done
just in an ordinary tone of voice,
and that held
no matter how big
the issue was.
It didn't matter
what the difference was
or anything.
We'd just talk it over
and make a decision,
go one way or the other
or go halfway between.
And that was a wonderful thing.
Although there were times
when I tried to crowd
more load onto him,
and I had a hell of a time
to get him to take over
the responsibility of the equipment.
I'd want a couple of new trucks
and by God,
he'd hum-hum-haw around,
hum-haw around,
get prices,
and he'd come back to me
and say,
which ones should we buy?
I'd say,
Art, I don't give a damn
which ones you buy.
I said,
you're the guy
that's going to have to look after them.
There isn't a hundred dollars
difference in the price.
I said,
whatever you think.
I said,
if you think you want to spend
a thousand dollars
fixing that thing up,
go ahead and fix it.
If you want to do it for five hundred,
do it for five hundred.
You're the guy
that's got to keep it running.
And eventually he got
that he would take the responsibility.
But that took several years
and after he took over,
he had no problem.
When I went down there,
it wasn't to make any decisions.
It was estimating,
to help him estimate.
And he had done
a lot of estimating.
We used to both estimate a job.
And I had trained him
on estimating.
He had his method of doing it
and I had mine.
And it was amazing
how we could estimate a job
and come up with almost
the exact figure,
but both used a different method
of arriving at that figure.
But he was probably like I was.
He could multiply man hours
or so many men could do
so much work.
And you multiply that down to
unit prices,
how much per unit.
I'll relate some of the things
what experience says for you.
When he joined up with this fellow
they were taking on some big jobs.
They were bidding on a job
up in,
way up in Alaska's
Northwest Territories.
North of Whitehorse,
wherever Whitehorse is.
And I had looked at it on a map,
a great big map
and saw the route and everything
and tapped
to art.
They went up and looked at it
and come back and I talked to him
and found out what the terrain was
and everything.
There were three of them.
An outfit from Saskatoon
and Art and this other fellow
from Yorkton were going to bid
on it jointly.
They were up in the hotel
doing the estimating.
They had worked on three days
and they phoned me at the office.
I was running the office for Art
while he was up there.
They phoned me at the office,
come on up for happy hour,
we're finished.
I said,
I would want
one million
nine hundred
and eighty thousand dollars
to do that job.
He said, is that complete?
I said, yeah.
He said, my God,
we've been sitting here for three days
figuring and you're within
ten thousand dollars
of what we came up with for a figure.
He said, how did you get that figure?
I said, just dead reckoning.
He said, I talked over with Art
what the terrain was like
and everything.
It was a rough country.
You had a big job.
You had to haul the material.
Then another time they bid
right in the office.
This fellow from Yorkton
and Art would do the job.
They were bidding on stringing
a second circuit from Regina
to Estevan.
That's a hundred and twenty-five
or thirty miles.
One side of the line was hot
and you had to string the other side.
This was on big steel towers.
I walked in and this Glenn Thorpe
guy from Yorkton said,
how much for building that line
or stringing that line, Lindy?
I said, twelve hundred and fifty
dollars a tower.
He looked at me.
He said, crap,
that's just what we figured out.
We've been sitting here three days.
I said,
I figured it out.
What would it take to string that line?
That's what I came up with.
Another time they were doing a job
at Swift Current.
It was an odd job.
It had to be done while the river
froze over and they had to put
three ninety-foot poles on an island.
It was a hell of a job.
I had looked at the blueprint.
I took a look at that.
They said, so many men,
so many men here.
I said, thirty thousand bucks.
So,
this is what I said to myself.
So, when they
had to figure it out, I said,
how much you figure for that island job?
They said, twenty-four thousand dollars.
I said, thirty thousand dollars.
Now, you're going to do
that job separately.
Let me know who's the closest
when you're finished.
They never did let me know
whether I was right.
And I have a notion that I was right
and they were wrong or they'd
been bringing it up to me.
I had a guesstimation, I guess.
Guesstimation.
Another time we had built a line
up in Alberta. I may have said that earlier.
And Art Miller
was up there. It was way back in 49.
And they couldn't get this line
to stay in. It would kick out the fuses
as fast as they put them in.
And they had worked. All the engineers
from the Canadian utilities were out there
and they couldn't find the trouble.
Art phoned me at night.
I said, I'll tell you what you do
in the morning. You drive way out
there into that line where you
cross that big ravine.
And you probably find the wires
twisted there.
He said, why do you say that?
Because I said I drove over that line once
and I said this would be a beautiful
place to have a break in the wire
because you're looking at the trees
and you can't see it.
The next day he phoned at Norman
and he said, you were right.
The wires were bucked up there.
He said, we all looked pretty silly
and then phoned you and you tell us
because you looked into the trees
and you couldn't see it.
When they went back and took a second
look at it, they found out that's
where the trouble was.
A lot of times they'd phone in from
the country. They were up at Elrose
hooking up a town and they had trouble.
Funny things were happening to them
and I'm sitting at home and they
phoned me in. I said, what's happening?
I told them what to look for and
they found the trouble and that was it.
They had the same thing happen.
That was about
50 years later. The same thing happened
but a different form.
He couldn't figure out his trouble.
Then they sort of think you're a wise
guy, you know.
You come along and
the machine isn't working.
I come along and the boring machine
was in a grudge and the guy had
changed the carburetor, he changed
the carb, he did everything and the
motor wouldn't start.
I said, take the
switch blade off back here
before you turn the switch off.
Took it off.
The wires were disconnected in there.
They all looked at you.
They said, you're smart.
It's just a process of elimination.
They had tried everything else
but they hadn't tried that
so you tell them to try that.
I had a guy, Ray Booth.
He used to shake his head.
He said, how can you figure these things out?
I said, process of elimination.
That's all it is.
You ask the other guy what he's done first
and he's done everything else.
He hasn't done probably where the trouble is.
So that's the way it went from
a lifetime in power
from 1928
and then I wasn't finished.
I still had my finger
in the pie until about 1975
and since that
not much has...
They haven't called on me very often.
They've found out how to...
Another five years ago Art had
trouble. He couldn't
find the trouble.
He was in a
big government garage
and again I told him what to look for
and that's where he found the trouble.
I said it can't be anything else.
They were looking in the substation
and it wasn't in the substation at all.
It was right in the building.
So that's the way it goes.
I don't know how many more years
I'll be here to reminisce but
every once in a while
I get a smile when I think back
to some of the things that happened
when I started out.
Paying a laborer
40 cents an hour and he paid his own
room and board.
And now the minimum wage is
360 an hour
and you have to pay the room and board
and you pay holiday pay and everything.
None of that was
on the books when I started out.
You have so many things
that have changed.
People have become less reliable too.
I've found the more money they get
the less
they give them.
I don't know what it would be like
if I'd be running an outfit now.
Some of the old timers tell me
I wish you'd be out here sometime
and straighten things out.
I see what happens around here now
compared to what happened when you were there.
Well I said I probably wouldn't be able
to do much about it.
The laws have changed and the rules
and regulations have changed.
You've got to go along with it.
So I suppose after you listen to this
you may have a lot of questions to ask me.
To the women,
the girls,
this may not be of much interest
but Danny and Norm
should get something out of it.
They both worked out on the job
not a lot but enough
to get a smattering of what goes on.
And
they should get
not Norm so much
he's in the
banking end of it
but
Danny, he's just starting out
I was about his age
when I started in the power business
and it doesn't come fast
it comes one day at a time
one week at a time
one month at a time
one year at a time
and the main thing is
that you're always bettering your own position
use the old saying
day by day in every way
I'm getting better and better
and that will help you
as you go along.
When people see you
overnight
that's a long process to get up there.
I was probably
one of the lucky ones
in the fact that
when I was home
I was put in charge of things
from the time I was 19 years old
my dad died when I was 21
so I was in full charge of the farm
for the three years
I worked on power lines
less than two years
when I was made a foreman
and was never anything less than that
I worked my total career
so
it doesn't
fall that easy for everyone
some
have to work years and years and years
to get up the ladder
but I can say this
I never went to work in my life
when I was anxious to get to the job
and meet the challenge
of the day
regardless of what it was
and with that
I will say
over and out
please run this tape to the end
so that it will be ready to
roll on
side three
